perturbation.original_text: The Customer is solely responsible for all content on the Hosted Site, including but not limited to, HTML pages, graphics, sounds, animations, video clips, Java applets, client-site scripts such as JavaScript and VBScript features, ActiveX controls, and other files and/or executable components for use or download by the users of the Hosted Site, as well as the accuracy and validity of any information or data contained within, as well as the overall look-and-feel of the Hosted Site from a user's perspective.
perturbation.changed_text: The Customer is solely responsible for some content on the Hosted Site, which consists of HTML pages, graphics, sounds, animations, video clips, Java applets, client-site scripts such as JavaScript and VBScript features, ActiveX controls, and other files and/or executable components for use or download by the users of the Hosted Site, as well as the accuracy and validity of any information or data contained within, as well as the overall look-and-feel of the Hosted Site from a user's perspective.
perturbation.explanation: By changing 'all content' to 'some content' the customer's responsibility for copyright infringement is weakened. This contradicts copyright law that holds website owners responsible for all infringing content.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Copyright Law, specifically related to contributory and vicarious infringement.
perturbation.law_explanation: This modification weakens the customer's responsibility for copyright infringements on their website. By stating the customer is responsible for 'some' content, it implies they are not responsible for 'all' content, which could include copyrighted material uploaded by users. This contradicts copyright law that makes website owners liable for copyright infringement occurring on their site, including content uploaded by users, especially if they are aware of it.

perturbation.original_text: The Customer is responsible for any and all software programs, server-side scripts, and/or executable components that are installed on the Hosting Computer for the purpose of providing interactive applications or dynamic content on the Hosted Site. Any such programs, scripts, or components that might affect the stability of the Hosting Computer or interfere with other Web sites on the Hosting Computer must be approved by i-on before being installed on the Hosted Site, i-on reserves the right to deny the Customer permission to install any such programs, scripts, or components, to require additional fees for the installation and/or ongoing operation of any such programs, scripts, or components, or to remove any such programs, scripts, or components, if in i-on's sole discretion they will interfere with the operation of the Hosting Computer or exceed the Customer's monthly allocation of Web administration services.
perturbation.changed_text: The Customer is responsible for most software programs, server-side scripts, and/or executable components that are installed on the Hosting Computer for the purpose of providing interactive applications or dynamic content on the Hosted Site. Any such programs, scripts, or components that might affect the stability of the Hosting Computer or interfere with other Web sites on the Hosting Computer must be approved by i-on before being installed on the Hosted Site, i-on reserves the right to deny the Customer permission to install any such programs, scripts, or components, to require additional fees for the installation and/or ongoing operation of any such programs, scripts, or components, or to remove any such programs, scripts, or components, if in i-on's sole discretion they will interfere with the operation of the Hosting Computer or exceed the Customer's monthly allocation of Web administration services.
perturbation.explanation: By changing 'any and all' to 'most' the customer's responsibility for the software programs is weakened. This introduces ambiguity regarding liability for malicious software or security breaches.
perturbation.law_explanation: This modification reduces the customer's responsibility for all software on their hosted site. By changing 'any and all' to 'most,' it creates a loophole where the customer might claim they are not responsible for specific malicious software or scripts used for unauthorized access or damage, thus potentially violating the CFAA. The CFAA holds individuals accountable for damage caused by malicious software or unauthorized access to computer systems, and this clause weakens that responsibility.

perturbation.original_text: The Customer shall comply with applicable laws, standards, policies, and procedures. The Customer incurs the responsibility to determine what restrictions apply and to review the policies and procedures that will be updated continually.
perturbation.changed_text: The Customer may comply with suggested laws, standards, policies, and procedures. The Customer has the option to determine what restrictions apply and to review the policies and procedures that will be updated continually.
perturbation.explanation: Changing 'shall comply' to 'may comply' and 'responsibility' to 'option' weakens the customer's legal obligation to follow applicable laws. This introduces a contradiction to various regulatory compliance requirements.
perturbation.contradicted_law: General duty clause under OSHA (Occupational Safety and Health Act)
perturbation.law_explanation: This change weakens the customer's obligation to comply with all applicable laws. Specifically, replacing 'shall comply' with 'may comply' directly contradicts the general duty clause under OSHA (29 U.S. Code ยง 654), which requires employers to provide a safe workplace. By making compliance optional, the customer might disregard safety regulations, leading to potential violations of OSHA if their website activities impact employee safety (e.g., if employees use the website as part of their job).
